title: Kyushu University Reports Findings in Agroforestry (Cacao agroforestry adoption by smallholder farmers and forest loss prevention in the Maya Golden Landscape, Belize)
bodyText:
2025 JAN 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Japan Daily Report -- New research on Agriculture - Agroforestry is the subject of a report. According to news reporting from Fukuoka, Japan, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Unsustainable land use practices have led to increased forest loss rates. Implementing cacao agroforestry can reduce forest loss by preventing the clear-cutting of forests for monoculture plantations."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Kyushu University, "However, research is needed on its effectiveness in preventing forest loss and the factors influencing its adoption between full-time and part-time farmers. Here, we address these gaps in the Maya Golden Landscape, Belize, by using Mahalanobis distance matching to compare forest loss in cacao agroforestry concession, forest reserve, and de-reserve areas and analyzing social data of 187 households. The results suggest that the odds of forest loss in the cacao agroforestry concession area are approximately 16% higher than in the Maya Mountain North Forest Reserve. In comparison, they are 85% lower than in the de-reserved areas. We also report differences in the factors influencing agroforestry adoption between part-time and full-time farmers."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Successful cacao agroforestry adoption requires considering the differences that exist between farmers' categories."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Cacao agroforestry adoption by smallholder farmers and forest loss prevention in the Maya Golden Landscape, Belize. Ambio, 2024. Ambio can be contacted at: Springer, Van Godewijckstraat 30, 3311 Gz Dordrecht, Netherlands. (Springer - www.springer.com; Ambio - www.springerlink.com/content/0044-7447/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Santos Daniel Chicas, Dept. of Agro-Environmental Science, Faculty of Agriculture, Kyushu University, 744 Motooka Nishi-ku, Fukuoka, Japan. Additional authors for this research include Nobuya Mizoue, Tetsuji Ota, Khin Thu Wint Kyaw, Miguel Conrado Valdez, Jonas 0stergaard Nielsen and Chi-Farn Chen.
Publisher contact information for the journal Ambio is: Springer, Van Godewijckstraat 30, 3311 Gz Dordrecht, Netherlands.
Keywords for this news article include: Fukuoka, Japan, Asia, Agriculture, Agroforestry, Risk and Prevention.
Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2025, NewsRx LLC

SECTION 6 CORPORATE PROFILE

6.1 Activities

FRUTA FRUTA INC. imports, processes and sells Amazon fruit frozen pulp. The National Brand segment sells its own branded products, with Amazon fruits as its materials, to mass merchandisers, supermarkets, convenience stores and other retailers. The Agroforestry Marketing segment sells frozen fruit pulp and its processing products to eating out shops and food manufacturers, as well as sells to variety of companies the products other than frozen fruit pulp that can be in the field of agroforestry as raw materials. The Direct Marketing segment include the operation of Furutta Furutta Acai Cafe, Furutta Furutta Acai factory and other direct stores, as well as mail order using its own Website. It is 91st largest Food company by market capitalisation in Japan.

title: Studies from Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute Yield New Data on Soil Science and Plant Nutrition (Effects of Soil Types and Fertility Management Practices On Soil Silicon Availability and Banana Silicon Uptake)
bodyText:
2023 MAR 23 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Japan Daily Report -- Current study results on Life Sciences - Soil Science and Plant Nutrition have been published. According to news reporting originating from Tsukuba, Japan, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Although silicon (Si) is one of soil abundant constituents and one of the key elements enhancing plant disease resistance, banana uptake of Si is limited by soil Si availability. It remains unclear what factors regulates soil Si availability and whether banana Si uptake increases with increasing soil Si availability in home garden soils."


Financial support for this research came from Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.
Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute, "To test whether soil Si availability and banana leaf SiO2 contents are affected by soil types or fertility management practices, we measured (1) banana leaf SiO2 contents along the gradient of livestock inputs in Andisols of Tanzania and (2) water extractable Si, phosphate-buffer extractable Si, and banana leaf SiO2 in the home garden soils with different degree of volcanic ash admixing and with/without leguminous trees in Indonesia (East Java and East Kalimantan). Livestock dung application increased banana leaf SiO2 contents in the Tanzanian home gardens. Water extractable Si increased with increasing soil pH, but soil phosphate-buffer extractable Si and banana leaf SiO2 contents were strongly regulated by oxalate-extractable Si and andic properties in the Indonesian home gardens. Effects of companion trees (agroforestry) increased banana leaf SiO2 only in two of three Andisols (Java)."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "These results suggest that banana leaf SiO2 contents could be primarily regulated by admixing degree of volcanic parent materials rich in weatherable minerals, but that banana leaf SiO2 contents could also be increased by inputs of livestock dung rich in Si (Tanzania) and agroforestry (Indoensia)."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Effects of Soil Types and Fertility Management Practices On Soil Silicon Availability and Banana Silicon Uptake. Soil Science & Plant Nutrition, 2023. Soil Science & Plant Nutrition can be contacted at: Taylor & Francis Ltd, 2-4 Park Square, Milton Park, Abingdon OR14 4RN, Oxon, England. (Wiley-Blackwell - www.wiley.com/; Soil Science & Plant Nutrition - onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1747-0765)
The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Kazumichi Fujii, Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute, Tsukuba, Japan. Additional authors for this research include Yuri Ichinose, Kazuna Arai, Ken Komatsu, Chie Hayakawa, Dionisio de Guzman Alvindia, Kyoko Watanabe and Arief Hartono.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1080/00380768.2023.2175177. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Tsukuba, Japan, Asia, Soil Science and Plant Nutrition, Life Sciences, Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute.
Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2023, NewsRx LLC

Water extractable Si increased with increasing soil pH, but soil phosphate-buffer extractable Si and banana leaf SiO2 contents were strongly regulated by oxalate-extractable Si and andic properties in the Indonesian home gardens. According to the news editors, the research concluded: "These results suggest that banana leaf SiO2 contents could be primarily regulated by admixing degree of volcanic parent materials rich in weatherable minerals, but that banana leaf SiO2 contents could also be increased by inputs of livestock dung rich in Si (Tanzania) and agroforestry (Indoensia). This research has been peer-reviewed.

title: Asian editorial excerpts
bodyText:
Selected editorial excerpts from the Asia-Pacific press:

BONN, THE INTERSECTION (The Jakarta Post, Jakarta)

There was little excitement during the climate talks in Bonn. The Jubilation of Paris two years ago after participating countries agreed to form a global pact to reduce emissions in a bid to prevent more floods, heat waves and rising sea levels, has subsided.

As delegates prepared the rule book to implement the climate accord at the 23rd session of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Convention on Climate Change, they were bracing for the impact of the United States' exit.

As one of the biggest emitters and among countries that has provided significant funding to the global movement, the US pullout from the climate accord...has shifted the balance of the world's largest diplomatic convention.

There was a ring of solidarity, shared by developed and developing countries, expressing their firm commitment to the Paris accord.

However, much more than commitment is needed.

Scientists said countries had barely budged in reducing their emissions.

Political obstacles may also hamper talks on the allocation of funding and technology necessary to support other countries in upholding the global goal.

The two-week talks in Bonn have shown that it is the big countries that are reluctant to carry out the commitments.

For Indonesia, which still relies on technology and funding to meet its own goals, however, this is no excuse to slow down efforts to reduce emissions, especially in the forestry sector. The government, along with the private sector and citizens, have made significant achievements in reducing forest fires and improving agroforestry partnerships that have also begun to benefit locals.

The innovation and partnerships to reduce emissions in forestry will benefit the country in sustaining its land and forests. Indonesia could then show the way forward in the climate fight.

(Nov. 20)

==Kyodo

For Indonesia, which still relies on technology and funding to meet its own goals, however, this is no excuse to slow down efforts to reduce emissions, especially in the forestry sector. The innovation and partnerships to reduce emissions in forestry will benefit the country in sustaining its land and forests. Indonesia could then show the way forward in the climate fight.

title: J-Green 'rigged other bids'
bodyText:
Prosecutors searched branch offices and other locations of the Japan Green Resources Agency (J-Green) Friday on suspicion of bid-rigging in two large-scale projects in Kumamoto and Shimane prefectures, following previous allegations of bid-rigging in forest road projects.

The latest allegations involve forestry and agricultural development projects in mountainous areas, adopted primarily by the Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Ministry. J-Green, an independent administrative entity under the ministry, took on the two projects in Ogunimachi, Kumamoto Prefecture, and Gotsu, Shimane Prefecture.

The Tokyo District Public Prosecutors Office's special investigation squad has already arrested a former and a current J-Green official, along with four employees of its contractors, on suspicion of rigging bids for the agency's forest road survey consulting projects in fiscal 2005 and 2006. It now suspects J-Green also led bid-rigging in the two agroforestry projects.

For the Kumamoto Prefecture project, 5,700 hectares will be developed from fiscal 2003 to 2009 at a cost of 15.4 billion yen. The Shimane Prefecture project will cost 12 billion yen to develop 3,080 hectares from fiscal 2007 to 2013.

The prosecutors searched J-Green's Kyushu Branch Office in Fukuoka and the Kinki-Hokuriku Branch's Kyoto office, which ordered the projects.

For the Kumamoto Prefecture project, 5,700 hectares will be developed from fiscal 2003 to 2009 at a cost of 15. 4 billion yen.

bodyText:
African countries want Japan to increase its assistance to boost production of a resilient and high-yielding strain of rice known as new rice for Africa, or NERICA, the head of an Africa-based intergovernmental rice research group said Friday.

A steady growth in output of NERICA would free Africa from paying $1 billion a year in rice imports, Kanayo Nwanze, director general of the Africa Rice Center in Benin, said on the sidelines of a Tokyo conference on agricultural development in Africa.

Japan, which has been actively involved in developing NERICA, voiced its support for boosting African agriculture during last week's summit of the Group of Eight nations in Scotland, where the G-8 leaders agreed to increase aid for the continent by $50 billion in 2010 from the 2004 level.

'Demand for rice in West Africa is growing about 6 percent per year, but production has not kept pace with such high growth,' Nwanze told reporters. 'Since the 1960s, rice imports in Africa have increased eightfold to 4 million tons per year at an annual cost of more than $1 billion.'

He said rice is the most rapidly growing food source in Africa, and that it is grown and consumed in about 40 countries in the continent.

Agriculture experts say NERICA has brought hope to millions of poor people in Africa. It adapts to the harsh growing environment in sub-Saharan Africa, where small farmers lack the means to irrigate the land and apply chemical fertilizers or pesticides.

Nwanze said his organization, in collaboration with Japan and other donors, plans to expand NERICA cultivation in Africa to 200,000 hectares in 2007 from the current 140,000 hectares, of which 120,000 are in western Africa and the rest in eastern Africa.

NERICA combines the ruggedness of local African rice strains with the high productivity traits of the Asian rice that laid the foundation for the Green Revolution in Asia in the 1960s and 1970s.

Along with Nwanze, the Tokyo conference brought together representatives from the Washington-based Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research, Nairobi-based World Agroforestry Center, Syria-based International Center for Agricultural Research in the Dry Areas, India-based International Corps Research Institute for the Semi-Arid Tropics as well as the Japanese government.

NERICA combines the ruggedness of local African rice strains with the high productivity traits of the Asian rice that laid the foundation for the Green Revolution in Asia in the 1960s and 1970s.

bodyText:
Public-participation-style political processes are vital to realizing economic, social and environmental sustainability, an indigenous Ecuadorean governor said said Friday.

Auki Tituana was elected as the first indigenous governor of Cotacachi County in the South American country in 1996 and was invited to 2005 World Exposition Aichi as a guest lecturer.

"Everyone, from children to the elderly, should be regarded as equals, and each citizen can contribute to the reformation and development of their society. It's difficult, but it's not impossible," Tituana said.

Yomiuri

Scientists on Tuesday said they now know where a water plant blamed for killing Lake Victoria is getting many of its nutrients.

Satellite images have showed a flow of sediments entering the world's second largest freshwater lake from surrounding low-lying, deforested areas, said researchers from the Nairobi-based International Center for Research in Agroforestry (ICRAF).

The sediments contain the nutrients which feed floating hyacinths, water plants blamed for choking the lake's ecosystem.

The process is called eutrophication. It occurs when a body of water becomes enriched in dissolved nutrients that stimulate the growth of the aquatic plants.

Before the discovery of the nutrients' source, they had been widely believed to have originated from agricultural runoff.

'We noticed a dramatic plume of nitrogen- and phosphorous-rich sediments that are feeding the water hyacinth. This is one of the major causes of Lake Victoria's environmental demise,' said ICRAF Director General Pedro Sanchez.

'It surprised us to be able to apply land technology to lake water, and it led us in a new direction in terms of diagnosing Lake Victoria's environmental problems.'

The announcement was made jointly by the ICRAF and Washington-based Future Harvest, an organization aimed at showing the links between the environment and agriculture.

Lake Victoria, the chief reservoir of the Nile River, has been slowly dying over the last decade from the oversupply of nutrients and untreated sewage. The result has been a dwindling fish population, the spread of toxic algae and the rapid growth of floating hyacinths.

The plants are a problem because they deprive fish and plankton of oxygen and sunlight and lead to a reduction in the diversity of important aquatic plants. The weed's spread also blocks water traffic, further isolating remote regions.

In addition, the plant is blamed for stagnation of the lake's water, turning the shoreline into a breeding ground for mosquitoes that spread malaria and snails that carry a parasite that attacks the liver, lungs and eyes of humans.

So in effect, the plant threatens the livelihoods of at least 25 million people in Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania who depend on the lake for water, food and business.
instances: Scientists on Tuesday said they now know where a water plant blamed for killing Lake Victoria is getting many of its nutrients. The sediments contain the nutrients which feed floating hyacinths, water plants blamed for choking the lake's ecosystem. The process is called eutrophication.

bodyText:
An estimated $195 million over two years is needed to rehabilitate Afghanistan's agricultural sector in order to help the country fight poverty, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) said in a statement released Saturday.

The Manila-based bank said the estimate is based on a multi-donor assessment it coordinated that resulted in a draft final report outlining short- and medium-term frameworks for the war-torn country's economic recovery.

'There are enormous challenges, but Afghanistan's rural economy has substantial potential for recovery based on private sector-led growth, judicious management of water and other natural resources, and the provision of community-based, demand-driven services,' said ADB economist Allan Kelly, who led the assessment mission.

Kelly said a key challenge to attaining recovery for the country will be to find 'viable implementation and governance mechanisms.'

'This will require rebuilding an efficient institutional framework, revitalizing the roles of government at different levels, and fully exploiting the energy and initiative of rural communities and civil society,' he added.

The multi-donor report calls for a community-based, consultative approach to development and emphasizes the need to rehabilitate the country's irrigation systems that helped produce cash crops during the good years.

The report specifically urges the adoption of modern dry land farming technologies so that at least half the country's cereal needs can be met through rain-fed agriculture.

The report also includes detailed plans for technical assistance to support strategic planning, policy and institutional reform, and feasibility studies to prepare a medium-term investment program.

The assessment, conducted in two phases during February and April to May this year, comes on the heels of Afghanistan's efforts to emerge from decades of conflict and turmoil.

Agricultural output declined dramatically in the past decade.

Cereal yields, at about 0.6 tons per hectare of rain-fed land, are well below their potential. Irrigation systems are in disarray.

Agroforestry and horticulture, which once accounted for 40% of export earnings, now contribute only a small share to total agricultural output.

Livestock, which formerly provided an additional 40% of exports and was a principal source of cash income, is estimated to have been halved.

Afghanistan's rangelands have deteriorated due to drought, while fragile forests have been depleted by illegal logging and community demand for firewood.
instances: 6 tons per hectare of rain-fed land, are well below their potential. Irrigation systems are in disarray. Livestock, which formerly provided an additional 40% of exports and was a principal source of cash income, is estimated to have been halved. Afghanistan's rangelands have deteriorated due to drought, while fragile forests have been depleted by illegal logging and community demand for firewood.

title: FEATURE: Woman Building Organic Links with Ghanaian Cacao Growers
bodyText:
Tomoko Hoshino was appalled to learn by chance the bitter reality of child labor in cacao production in Western Africa after watching a television documentary during a stay in London in 2001.

Coming as it did in the same year as the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States, the recognition of the child labor issue drove home to Hoshino how little she, and many of her compatriots, know about affairs outside Japan.

For example, the production process of chocolate, made from roasted and ground cacao seeds, is not well known in Japan, although chocolate is a familiar item.

On the flip side, she thought, chocolate can raise awareness among Japanese of the close connection between their lives and people and environments overseas, including children who must work instead of attending school because of poverty.

Hoshino was motivated to launch an initiative to improve the status of producers by assisting in organic cacao production in Ghana.

"By bringing chocolate made from human- and earth-friendly cacao to Japanese consumers, I'd like to create a happy bond between producers and those who enjoy chocolate," says Hoshino, 49, founder and director of Choco-Revo International, a Tokyo-based general incorporated association.

Helping Producers

Set up in October 2011, Choco-Revo International not only supports a local nongovernmental organization but also is involved in the whole production process, ranging from cacao production and procurement to chocolate product development.

"We support cacao production that pays attention to the protection of forests and biodiversity and share information on our activities with all those involved in the supply chain," she says.

Choco-Revo International opts not to call for a boycott of chocolate made from cacao beans associated with child labor. It rather hopes to see voluntary participation of consumers in the efforts of businesses and NGOs to help cacao producers.

According to the Chocolate and Cocoa Association of Japan, cacao from Ghana accounts for about 80 pct of Japan's cacao imports. Ghana is the second largest cacao producer in the world, after Ivory Coast.

Around 1999, cacao prices plummeted due in part to market speculation, which led to an increase in the number of children being used as cheap labor, Hoshino says.

In Ghana, forests were badly damaged by persistent use of chemical fertilizers and clearing for the cultivation of cacao beans. Due to falling production and incomes, farmers could not afford school for their children, creating a vicious cycle that kept them in poverty.

Hoshino visited Ghana in 2007 for a firsthand look at a forest preservation project launched by Ricoh Co. , a Japanese office equipment manufacturer that promotes environmental protection as part of its social contribution.

In her visit to a local cacao production site, she witnessed scars of deforestation.

But thanks to the efforts of Ricoh and a local NGO since 2002, including reduction in the use of agricultural chemicals to raise soil nutrition, cacao production had increased. So had the number of children going to school.

According to a survey of local cacao producers conducted by Hoshino and Ricoh representatives in 2007, incomes had grown by two to eight times, while 90 pct of respondents claimed all their children go to school.

Hoshino is focusing on sustainable agroforestry.

Cacao trees can live 100 years if properly cared for. In the Hoshino-led project, many old cacao trees cultivated under nonorganic farming methods have been gradually replaced with seedlings, which are grown organically together with a diverse range of plants.

Network of Support

In 2008, Hoshino, then head of a preparatory committee to set up Choco-Revo International, held talks with representatives from a chocolate producer, a food trader and an NGO, all from Japan, on the development of products for Japan.

The following year, the initiative of her group was recognized by the Japan External Trade Organization as a development import project for which local information and financial support are provided by the government-linked organization to help the group prepare for imports.

With the aid of JETRO, Hoshino's group teamed up with COFA, a Ghanaian producer union that was the first in the African country to obtain organic certification in cacao production. It imported 3,000 pieces of chocolate produced in Ghana, and sold them at department stores operated by Marui Group Co. and Takashimaya Co. in January 2010.

In 2011, backed in part by Japanese companies, 30,000 cacao seedlings were planted in land owned by COFA member farmers. They are growing well and will start producing cacao in about five years.

The network of support for cacao producers in Ghana is growing steadily.

This year, on Feb. 14, St. Valentine's Day, chocolates from Choco-Revo International went on sale at three department store chains, including Odakyu Department Store Co. Chocolates made in collaboration with Mary Chocolate Co. were also released.

In Japan, women customarily give chocolates to men on St. Valentine's Day.

"Not only chocolate," Hoshino says. "When you choose a variety of products, I hope you exercise your imagination and consider by whom and how they were produced."
instances: So had the number of children going to school. According to a survey of local cacao producers conducted by Hoshino and Ricoh representatives in 2007, incomes had grown by two to eight times, while 90 pct of respondents claimed all their children go to school. Cacao trees can live 100 years if properly cared for. In the Hoshino-led project, many old cacao trees cultivated under nonorganic farming methods have been gradually replaced with seedlings, which are grown organically together with a diverse range of plants.

title: Full text of communique by G-20 leaders -4-
bodyText:
51. We acknowledge the efforts of those G20 and non-G20 countries committed to national coordination platforms and strategies for financial inclusion under the "G20 Financial Inclusion Peer Learning Program" and encourage similar efforts to advance effective implementation of the G20 Principles for Innovative Financial Inclusion such as the commitments to concrete actions to promote financial inclusion made by developing and emerging countries under the Maya Declaration, recognizing the ongoing efforts and the support by the World Bank Group and the Alliance for Financial Inclusion, and other stakeholders including the United Nations (UN), and bilateral donors to foster financial inclusion.

52. On financial education, we endorse the OECD/International Network on Financial Education (INFE) High Level Principles on National Strategies for Financial Education, and call on the OECD/INFE and the World Bank in cooperation with the GPFI to deliver further tools to promote financial education, with a progress report to the next Summit. For advancing the financial consumer protection agenda, we take note of the discussion on the Statutes of the International Financial Consumer Protection Network (FinCoNet) and on the issues of formal structure and financial support to ensure the exchange of best practices. We also endorse the Action Plan presented by the G20/OECD Task Force on Financial Consumer Protection to develop effective approaches to support the implementation of the High Level Principles on Financial Consumer Protection, and look forward to an update report by the Leaders' Summit in St. Petersburg in 2013.

53. We recognize the need for women and youth to gain access to financial services and financial education, ask the GPFI, the OECD/INFE, and the World Bank to identify barriers they may face and call for a progress report to be delivered by the next Summit.

54. We welcome the launch of the Mexico Financial Inclusion Challenge: Innovative Solutions for Unlocking Access, a call for innovations that address barriers to financial inclusion through the creation of valuable, affordable, secure, and comprehensive financial services.

55. The Action Plan on Food Price Volatility and Agriculture adopted by the Ministers of Agriculture in 2011 underlined that to feed a world population expected to exceed 9.3 billion by 2050, agricultural production will have to increase between 50 and 70 percent, and by almost 100 percent in developing countries. We recognize that increasing production and productivity on a sustainable basis while considering the diversity of agricultural conditions is one of the most important challenges that the world faces today. The crisis in the Sahel and the Horn of Africa also underscores that strengthening emergency and long-term responses to food insecurity remains a pressing challenge. We also note that chronic malnutrition is an enormous drain on a country's human resources, and we therefore support the Scaling Up Nutrition movement and encourage wider involvement of G20 members.

56. We welcome the considerable progress made in implementing the Action Plan and the food security pillar of the Seoul Multi-Year Action Plan on Development. We support the G20 Agriculture Vice-Ministers' Report annexed to this Declaration, on the progress made on previous commitments and key recommendations on sustainably increasing agricultural productivity, containing inputs from several international organizations coordinated by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the OECD, in addition to other recommendations from B20 and civil society.

57. To fight hunger, we commit to continue our efforts on our initiatives, including the Tropical Agriculture Platform, the Platform for Agricultural Risk Management, the GEO Global Agriculture Monitoring, research initiatives for wheat, rice and corn, the Rapid Response Forum, regional emergency food reserves, the Global Agriculture and Food Security Program and support for the Principles of Responsible Agriculture Investment. Recognizing the important contribution of greater transparency to reducing food price volatility, we welcome the progress made in the implementation of the Agricultural Market Information System (AMIS). We recognize that a more stable, predictable, distortion-free, open and transparent trading system, including as regards agriculture, has a critical role to play to promote food security.

58. We reaffirm our commitment to remove export restrictions and extraordinary taxes on food purchased for non-commercial humanitarian purposes by the World Food Programme (WFP). We encourage the implementation of the Voluntary Guidelines on the Responsible Governance of Tenure of Land, Fisheries and Forests in the Context of National Food Security.

59. We strongly welcome the launch of the "AgResults" Initiative, aimed at improving food security for the poor and vulnerable by encouraging private sector innovation of new agricultural products and systems constrained by market failures in agriculture. We look forward to the launch of the pilot projects focused on innovations in nutrient-fortified crops, post-harvest waste-reducing storage solutions and crop quality technologies in Sub-Saharan Africa. We commend those who have already committed or signaled their intention to commit funding to this initiative and encourage broader participation.

60. We recognize the need to adapt agriculture to climate change and we recognize the importance of improving the efficiency of water and soil use in a sustainable manner. To this end, we support the development of and a greater use of available technologies, well-known practices and techniques such as soil fertility enhancement, minimum tillage and agroforestry, and call upon international organizations to provide a report on science-based options to improve the efficiency of water use in agriculture including in ways particularly suitable for small farms.

61. We recognize the importance to the global economic recovery of maintaining stability in international commodity markets. We stress the importance of well-functioning and transparent physical and financial commodities' markets and reduced excessive price volatility to achieve food security and strong growth that is both sustainable and inclusive. We recognize that excessive commodity price volatility has significant implications for all countries, increasing uncertainty for actors in the economy and potentially hampering stability of the budgets, and predictability of economic planning. We recognize that mitigating the negative effects of commodity price volatility on the most vulnerable is an important component of reducing poverty and boosting economic growth. We therefore endorse the conclusions of the G20 report on the macroeconomic impacts of excessive commodity price volatility on growth and its identification of policy options that countries could consider, taking account of national circumstances to mitigate any such effect. We also acknowledge and appreciate the participation and valuable inputs of the IMF, World Bank and UNCTAD. We ask our Finance Ministers to report in 2013 on progress on the G20's contribution to facilitate better functioning of these physical markets, taking note of possible areas of further work outlined in the report. We reaffirm our commitment to enhance transparency and avoid abuse in financial commodity markets, including OTC, with effective intervention powers for market regulators and authorities and an appropriate regulation and supervisory framework. In this regard we look forward to IOSCO's report on the implementation of its recommendations on commodity derivatives markets by November 2012.

62. We recognize that excessive price volatility in energy commodities is also an important source of economic instability. We remain committed to well-functioning and transparent energy markets. We will continue to work to improve the timeliness, completeness and reliability of JODI-Oil and look forward to a progress report next year. We will work on the JODI-Gas database on the same principles. We expect the International Energy Forum (IEF) report on improving the reliability of the JODI-Oil database and the report on transparency in international gas and coal markets submitted by the International Energy Agency (IEA), IEF, and Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) to be discussed by our Finance Ministers in November. We also look forward to IOSCO's recommendations to improve the functioning and oversight of Price Reporting Agencies in November 2012, which will be produced in collaboration with other mandated organizations (IEF, IEA and OPEC), and task Finance Ministers to take concrete measures in this area as necessary.

63. Eradicating poverty and achieving strong, inclusive, sustainable and balanced growth remain core objectives of the G20 development agenda. We reaffirm our commitment to work with developing countries, particularly low income countries, and to support them in implementing the nationally driven policies and priorities which are needed to fulfill internationally agreed development goals, particularly the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and beyond.

64. We welcome the initiative of the Development Working Group to build upon the work of previous G20 presidencies, and its focus on three priorities during the Mexican Presidency - food security, infrastructure and inclusive green growth. We commend the progress achieved against our commitments in the Seoul Multi-Year Action Plan, and support the 2012 Development Working Group progress report annexed to this Declaration. We invite the Development Working Group to explore putting in place a process for ensuring assessment and accountability for G20 development actions by the next Summit.

65. Investment in infrastructure is critical for sustained economic growth, poverty reduction, and job creation. We therefore welcome the strong progress made under the Multi-Year Action Plan, including in implementing the recommendations of the Multilateral Development Banks' (MDBs) Action Plan and the High Level Panel on Infrastructure. (MORE)
instances: 60. We recognize the need to adapt agriculture to climate change and we recognize the importance of improving the efficiency of water and soil use in a sustainable manner. 61. We recognize the importance to the global economic recovery of maintaining stability in international commodity markets.

bodyText:
The Ujung Kulon National Park, a region of pristine rain forests and abundant wildlife, is a World Heritage Site with a dilemma.

In an age of increasing ecotourism, it needs the money a boost in visitors would bring to help preserve its environment. But that very increase could threaten the environment and destroy the balance of the region's ecosystem.

The park is located on the southwestern tip of the island of Java. To reach it requires at least four hours by land from Jakarta to Labuan Port, one main entry point, and from there a five-hour boat trip.

Because of its isolation, Ujung Kulon remains an outpost of primeval forest and untouched wilderness on heavily developed Java. But despite its remoteness and the relatively high cost of visiting the park, the diversity of its wildlife is gradually making it a popular destination.

Signs that city dwellers have their eyes on the area can be seen in the new resorts, houses and condominiums mushrooming on the way to Labuan Port.

The park's management plans to attract more visitors to enjoy the dense rain forests, the long stretches of sandy beach and the variety of wildlife.

Ron Lilley, coordinator of species conservation at the World Wide Fund for Nature's Indonesia Program, said ecotourism could promote Ujung Kulon which 'needs money to conserve its environment' but at the same time could result in environmental damage, even though such tourism tries to combine a commitment to nature with a sense of social responsibility.

'When people do business, they think only of profit,' he said, adding that philosophical ideals often end up being a means to an end.

The Forest Protection and Nature Conservation, a directorate under the Indonesian Forestry Ministry, receives a limited annual budget of 16 billion rupiah (2 million U.S. dollars) to preserve the environment across the archipelago, which comprises 17,000 islands with 144 million hectares of forests and 81,000 kilometers of beaches.

Researcher Sudhiani Pratiwi said the concept of ecotourism combines the pleasure of discovering and understanding spectacular flora and fauna with efforts to protect them from destruction.

Many conservationists, however, say such a concept only delays destruction and does not prevent it from happening.

Rommy, an official with Kalpataru Adventure, a club that offers guide services for visitors to Ujung Kulon, has already noted water pollution resulting from motorboat transportation between the islands in the park, beaten tracks in the forests and piles of garbage left on beaches.

Sometimes, he said, the visitors he accompanies on nature walks shout in awe at what they see, frightening animals in the park and disrupting its harmony rather than being quiet and simply enjoying the wonders of nature.

Sudhiani said good cooperation between conservation agencies and business is needed to enable human resources to deal with the task of nature preservation and to handle greater numbers of visitors.

Currently, the government says only 10% of the whole area can be utilized for tourist purposes, but the park management's plan to attract more visitors has raised questions about whether the government will allow an increase in tourists.

One of the greatest challenges will be to gain the support of local communities living on the fringes of the park and educate them about the need to protect the forest and its wildlife.

In the villages around the park, the WWF currently runs a Primary Environmental Care educational program, encouraging residents to find alternative resources and income rather than poaching marine life as many still do. The WWF also teaches local people to develop agroforestry and cottage industries.

German botanical expert F. Junghuhn first introduced Ujung Kulon to the world in 1846 and since then attention has focused on its biodiversity. It became the first national park in Indonesia in 1980, and in 1992 was named as a World Heritage Site.

Spreading over a vast area, the park comprises 76,214 hectares of land and 44,337 hectares of surrounding reefs and sea.

It can be broadly separated into three areas -- the triangular Ujung Kulon peninsula, the Gunung Honje range to the east of the peninsula's isthmus, and the offshore islands of Panaitan, Peucang and Handeuleum to the northwest.

The main park area is on the peninsula, which is mostly dense lowland rain forest and a mixture of scrub, grassy plains, swamps, palms and long stretches of sandy beach on the west and south coasts.

The park is best known as the last home of the once plentiful one-horned Javanese rhinoceros, now numbering only at 47, according to a WWF survey in 1993.

In addition to the Javanese rhino, the park is also the habitat of other endangered animals such as the porcupine, peafowl, monitor lizard and long-tailed macaque, as well as a wide variety of birds.

Crocodiles also live in the river estuaries and green turtles in the sea.

But whether ecotourism can live up to its ideals, whether these creatures and their habitat will survive the invasion of the human species, with its fevered curiosity and thirst for entertainment, is something only the next century will reveal.
instances: One of the greatest challenges will be to gain the support of local communities living on the fringes of the park and educate them about the need to protect the forest and its wildlife. In the villages around the park, the WWF currently runs a Primary Environmental Care educational program, encouraging residents to find alternative resources and income rather than poaching marine life as many still do. German botanical expert F. Junghuhn first introduced Ujung Kulon to the world in 1846 and since then attention has focused on its biodiversity.

bodyText:
Japan plans to make an initial grant of 68,000 dollars to establish an agroforestry training center in eastern Myanmar's Lake Inlay area, aimed at curbing the environmental degradation of Lake Inlay which supplies water to Lawpita hydroelectric power station, the Japanese Embassy said Tuesday.

Lawpita power station, the biggest power source in Myanmar, was built with Japanese assistance in the 1950s.

Lake Inlay is threatened with loss of topsoil, silting and other natural environmental degradation affecting its water level.

The project will be carried out by a Japanese nongovernmental organization, Karamosia International, in cooperation with the Myanmar Forestry Department.

An agreement for the initial grant was signed Tuesday in Yangon by Japanese Ambassador Kazuo Asakai and Kenichi Kato, president of Karamosia International, according to the embassy.

The proposed training center will provide an integrated environmental education program for the local community and offer scholarships for training in Japan, in the field of agriculture and forestry.
instances: Lawpita power station, the biggest power source in Myanmar, was built with Japanese assistance in the 1950s. Lake Inlay is threatened with loss of topsoil, silting and other natural environmental degradation affecting its water level.

title: Japan Okinawa Agricultural Research Station Develops Two Weather-Proof Sugarcane Varieties
bodyText: SOURCE: Okinawa Times

Japan will extend a grant of 90,400 dollars to help create an agroforestry training center in Myanmar, the Japanese Embassy in Yangon said Friday.

A Japanese nongovernmental organization will build the training center at Yezagyo, about 500 kilometers north of Yangon.
instances: A Japanese nongovernmental organization will build the training center at Yezagyo, about 500 kilometers north of Yangon.

bodyText:
Oil distributors Nippon Oil Corp. and Idemitsu Kosan Co. said Tuesday they have agreed to contribute money to the World Bank-sponsored fund designed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in a bid to fight global warming.

The two firms said they will put up $2.5 million each over the next 20 years for the Community Development Carbon Fund (CDCF), which was created by the World Bank last fall with money contributed by governments and companies in industrial countries.

The CDCF will provide financing for reducing greenhouse gas emissions to small-scale projects in small developing countries and rural areas of all developing countries, according to the World Bank.

The emphasis within the CDCF will be on renewable energy, energy efficiency, solid waste to energy conversion, and agroforestry projects, with significant and measurable community development benefits.
instances: 5 million each over the next 20 years for the Community Development Carbon Fund (CDCF), which was created by the World Bank last fall with money contributed by governments and companies in industrial countries. The CDCF will provide financing for reducing greenhouse gas emissions to small-scale projects in small developing countries and rural areas of all developing countries, according to the World Bank.

title: 値段の高さでも､生産地でもない…"最高においしいコーヒー"を見分けるプロが､メニューで注目するポイント
bodyText: おいしいコーヒーを選ぶには、何を見ればいいのか。『世界のビジネスエリートが身につけている コーヒーの教養』（あさ出版）を書いた山本博文さんは「コーヒーには3つの品質基準が設けられている。中でも『スペシャルティ』は最も品質が高く、香りも素晴らしい。カフェなどを訪れた際にも見分ける方法がある」という――。（第2回） ■コーヒーは大きく3つの品質にわけられる コーヒーには、大きく分けて3つの品質基準があり、香味や欠点豆の数によってコモディティ、プレミアム、スペシャルティに分類されます。なぜこのような分類があるかと言うと、コーヒーの国際取引において買い手側がどういった品質を求めているか、売り手側がどのような品質のものを作っているかといった共通の認識がないと、コミュニケーションが難しくなるためです。 コモディティとは一般商品、つまり、一定の輸出規格に則って生産されるコーヒーのことです。取引価格は、生豆の輸出規格とコーヒー相場（ディファレンシャルを含む）をもとに決められます。 輸出規格とは「格付け」や「グレード」とも呼ばれ、コーヒーの品質を示すものです。各生産国の生産環境によって独自に設定されるのですが、次の4つをもとにしていることが多いです。 ・産地の標高 ・カップテストによる香味の品質 ・生豆の大きさ（スクリーンサイズ） ・欠点豆（コーヒー生産の過程で出てくる不良品のようなもの）の数...

title: スタバ店員にも｢おすすめはありますか?｣と必ず尋ねる…コーヒー好きが｢とりあえずブラック｣と言わない理由
bodyText: コーヒーを深く楽しむためには、どんなことに注目したらいいのか。『世界のビジネスエリートが身につけている コーヒーの教養』（あさ出版）を書いた山本博文さんは「コーヒーの味わいは、酸味や苦みなど5つの要素で表現できる。自分の好みがわかると、品種や香りの違いも感じられるようになる。日常のカフェなどでも試せる飲み方のコツがある」という――。（第1回） ■“自分好みの焙煎度”を知る コーヒーの味わいを言葉で表現する時、よく使われるのは、「甘み」「酸味」「苦み」「ボディ感」「香り」の5つです。それぞれバランスによって、様々なコーヒーの味を大まかに分けることができます。 しかし、実際にコーヒーを飲んでいきなり全ての味を感じることは難しいと思いますので、まずは大きく、「苦みか酸味か」「スッキリ軽めの味わいかコクの深い味わいか」という2つの軸で飲み比べ、コーヒーの味を分解していきましょう。 その時に役立つのがコーヒーの「飲み比べ」です。深煎り、中深煎り、中煎り、浅煎りそれぞれのコーヒーを飲んで、味の違いを感じてみましょう。そうすることで、「自分は苦みの強い深煎りコーヒーが好きだな」とか、「コクの深い中深煎りが好きだな」とか、「酸味と甘みを感じる浅煎りが好きだな」ということが分かってきます。...

bodyText: コーヒーを深く楽しむためには、どんなことに注目したらいいのか。『世界のビジネスエリートが身につけている コーヒーの教養』(あさ出版)を書いた山本博文さんは「コーヒーの味わいは、酸味や苦みなど5つの要素で表現できる。自分の好みがわかると、品種や香りの違いも感じられるようになる。日常のカフェなどでも試せる飲み方のコツがある」という――。(第1回) ■“自分好みの焙煎度”を知る 　コーヒーの味わいを言葉で表現する時、よく使われるのは、「甘み」「酸味」「苦み」「ボディ感」「香り」の5つです。それぞれバランスによって、様々なコーヒーの味を大まかに分けることができます。 　しかし、実際にコーヒーを飲んでいきなり全ての味を感じることは難しいと思いますので、まずは大きく、「苦みか酸味か」「スッキリ軽めの味わいかコクの深い味わいか」という2つの軸で飲み比べ、コーヒーの味を分解していきましょう。 　その時に役立つのがコーヒーの「飲み比べ」です。深煎り、中深煎り、中煎り、浅煎りそれぞれのコーヒーを飲んで、味の違いを感じてみましょう。そうすることで、「自分は苦みの強い深煎りコーヒーが好きだな」とか、「コクの深い中深煎りが好きだな」とか、「酸味と甘みを感じる浅煎りが好きだな」ということが分かってきます。...

title: 値段の高さでも､生産地でもない…"最高においしいコーヒー"を見分けるプロが､メニューで注目するポイント
bodyText: おいしいコーヒーを選ぶには、何を見ればいいのか。『世界のビジネスエリートが身につけている コーヒーの教養』（あさ出版）を書いた山本博文さんは「コーヒーには3つの品質基準が設けられている。中でも『スペシャルティ』は最も品質が高く、香りも素晴らしい。カフェなどを訪れた際にも見分ける方法がある」という――。（第2回）■コーヒーは大きく3つの品質にわけられる コーヒーには、大きく分けて3つの品質基準があり、香味や欠点豆の数によってコモディティ、プレミアム、スペシャルティに分類されます。なぜこのような分類があるかと言うと、コーヒーの国際取引において買い手側がどういった品質を求めているか、売り手側がどのような品質のものを作っているかといった共通の認識がないと、コミュニケーションが難しくなるためです。 コモディティとは一般商品、つまり、一定の輸出規格に則って生産されるコーヒーのことです。取引価格は、生豆の輸出規格とコーヒー相場（ディファレンシャルを含む）をもとに決められます。 輸出規格とは「格付け」や「グレード」とも呼ばれ、コーヒーの品質を示すものです。各生産国の生産環境によって独自に設定されるのですが、次の4つをもとにしていることが多いです。 ・産地の標高 ・カップテストによる香味の品質 ・生豆の大きさ（スクリーンサイズ） ・欠点豆（コーヒー生産の過程で出てくる不良品のようなもの）の数■品質を読み解いてみる 例えば、ブラジルの場合、輸出規格は、一定のサンプル中に含まれている欠点豆の数、生豆の粒の大きさ、そして香味の3つによって決められています。取引時に交わす契約書には、「No.2,...

title: 2025/07/11ITTOウェビナー、クローン技術による持続可能なチーク生産の可能性に焦点
bodyText: タイ北部にあるチーク改良センター研究所での組織培養技術の実演。写真: Alfredo Ruzol 組織培養技術で生産されたチークは、世界中の商業用プランテーションで既に高い収率と大きな利益をもたらしています。しかし、小規模農業従事者がこのような改良された造林資材を手にするのは、依然として困難であると言えます。 上記は、ITTOの旗艦プロジェクト（Promoting quality timber production in smallholders and community-based teak and other valuable species plantations in the tropics）の一環として2025年6月17日に行われたウェビナーの結論の一つです。同プロジェクトは、小規模農業従事者のチーク生産を促進し、世界で最も価値のある熱帯木材種の一つであるチークの持続可能な栽培と貿易を強化することを目的としています。 「組織培養によるチーク苗木のイノベーション」と題した同ウェビナーでは、アジア太平洋地域や西アフリカ諸国から参加者が集まり、商業目的のユーザーと小規模ユーザーの双方を対象にしたクローン苗木の開発と可能性に関する発表が行われました。 ウェビナーではまず、マレーシア・サバにある、YSGバイオスケープ・スディリアン有限会社のマネージング・ディレクターであるドーリーン・ゴー氏が、世界25カ国以上にクローン技術によるチーク苗木を輸出している同社の取組について説明しました。 ゴー博士はまず、種からの伝統的なチークの増殖における制約について説明しました。これには、高品質な種の供給が限られていること、発芽率の予測不能性、および、成長率・品質・ストレス耐性などの主要な特性のばらつきの大きさが含まれます。 クローン・コレクションでは、選択された標本（プラスツリー）を収集し、一貫した環境条件下で試験的に栽培します。写真: Alfredo Ruzol 一方、実験室での栄養繁殖（クローン増殖）では、特定の優れた特性を持つ母樹1本から採取した材料を使用し、同一の植物を無限に生産できます。 ゴー博士は、サバ財団の傘下にある自社の研究開発について、フランス農業開発研究国際協力センター（CIRAD）と協力し、ソロモン諸島で発見された8本の標本木からチークの造林素材を開発したと述べました。...

title: ITTOウェビナー、クローン技術による持続可能なチーク生産の可能性に焦点
bodyText: タイ北部にあるチーク改良センター研究所での組織培養技術の実演。写真: Alfredo Ruzol 組織培養技術で生産されたチークは、世界中の商業用プランテーションで既に高い収率と大きな利益をもたらしています。しかし、小規模農業従事者がこのような改良された造林資材を手にするのは、依然として困難であると言えます。 上記は、ITTOの旗艦プロジェクト（Promoting quality timber production in smallholders and community-based teak and other valuable species plantations in the tropics）の一環として2025年6月17日に行われたウェビナーの結論の一つです。同プロジェクトは、小規模農業従事者のチーク生産を促進し、世界で最も価値のある熱帯木材種の一つであるチークの持続可能な栽培と貿易を強化することを目的としています。 「組織培養によるチーク苗木のイノベーション」と題した同ウェビナーでは、アジア太平洋地域や西アフリカ諸国から参加者が集まり、商業目的のユーザーと小規模ユーザーの双方を対象にしたクローン苗木の開発と可能性に関する発表が行われました。 ウェビナーではまず、マレーシア・サバにある、YSGバイオスケープ・スディリアン有限会社のマネージング・ディレクターであるドーリーン・ゴー氏が、世界25カ国以上にクローン技術によるチーク苗木を輸出している同社の取組について説明しました。 ゴー博士はまず、種からの伝統的なチークの増殖における制約について説明しました。これには、高品質な種の供給が限られていること、発芽率の予測不能性、および、成長率・品質・ストレス耐性などの主要な特性のばらつきの大きさが含まれます。 クローン・コレクションでは、選択された標本（プラスツリー）を収集し、一貫した環境条件下で試験的に栽培します。写真: Alfredo Ruzol 一方、実験室での栄養繁殖（クローン増殖）では、特定の優れた特性を持つ母樹1本から採取した材料を使用し、同一の植物を無限に生産できます。 ゴー博士は、サバ財団の傘下にある自社の研究開発について、フランス農業開発研究国際協力センター（CIRAD）と協力し、ソロモン諸島で発見された8本の標本木からチークの造林素材を開発したと述べました。...
